title: RS22794
content: Political instability in Georgia escalated in November 2007 as opposition parties formed a "National Council" and held demonstrations in Tbilisi demanding early legislative elections in 2008. Former defense minister Irakli Okruashvili accused President Mikheil Saakashvili of ordering murder, leading to calls for Saakashvili's resignation. Police dispersed demonstrators, resulting in injuries, and shut down the independent Imedi television station. Saakashvili declared a state of emergency. Saakashvili declared a state of emergency for 15 days, claiming the demonstrations were part of a coup attempt orchestrated by Russia. He ordered three Russian diplomats to leave the country and stepped down as president on November 25, 2007, to hold early presidential elections on January 5, 2008. Legislative Speaker Nino Burjanadze became acting president and called for a plebiscite on spring or fall legislative elections and Georgia's NATO membership. Imedi television station resumed broadcasts on December 12. Imedi television station resumed broadcasts on December 12, serving as the main outlet for opposition candidates in the election. Amendments to the electoral code were made to enhance democracy, but haphazard implementation of new rules was noted by the OSCE. The nomination process for presidential candidates was considered inclusive and transparent, with Saakashvili and six others successfully registered. Saakashvili campaigned on reducing corruption, crime, and poverty, and improving living conditions. Several presidential candidates in Georgia pledged to improve living conditions, reduce poverty, and restore territorial integrity peacefully. They proposed various political systems, with some emphasizing freedom of speech, social services, and business creation. Most candidates supported Georgia's NATO membership, except for Irina Sarishvili-Chanturia and Badri Patarkatsishvili. Sarishvili-Chanturia urged voters to consider her or other preferred candidates. Badri Patarkatsishvili campaigned for presidency in Georgia, proposing a confederation with a weak central government and close ties with Russia. He faced accusations of involvement in a coup attempt and campaigned from abroad. The government released recordings incriminating him in another coup planned after the election, which he denied. Patarkatsishvili denied planning a coup and initially said he would step down as a candidate but later changed his mind. Imedi, partially owned by him, temporarily stopped transmissions. Saakashvili won over 50% of the votes to avoid a second round of voting. Voters supported Georgia joining NATO and holding legislative elections in spring 2008. An attempt to conduct balloting in South Ossetia was criticized by officials there. Saakashvili's election victory was attributed to a strong economy, improved social services, and promises to address poverty. The opposition's disunity was a significant factor in the election results. Observers from OSCE, PACE, and EP found the election to be mostly consistent with democratic standards, despite significant challenges and pervasive violations. The race offered a competitive choice of candidates, but issues-based discussions were hindered by the violations. The election campaign for Saakashvili was marred by pervasive violations, including the use of government offices to support him, harassment of opposition campaigners, allegations of state employees being forced to vote for him, and a pro-Saakashvili bias by the CEC. The vote count was viewed negatively by monitors, with many assessing it as bad. Electoral abuses varied by region and were often due to incompetence or local fraud. The CEC and courts invalidated or corrected results in 18 precincts. Fair Elections NGO reported on January 10 about the election. Fair Elections NGO reported on January 10 that Saakashvili may have won enough votes to avoid a runoff, despite voting irregularities. U.S. analyst Charles Fairbanks disputed the results, suggesting that Saakashvili's reported votes were inflated. Russian Foreign Ministry criticized the election as not free and fair due to the use of administrative resources and pressure on opposition candidates. The election campaign was relatively peaceful compared to previous violence, hinting at potential democratization efforts. Saakashvili's re-election in January 2008 was seen as a positive sign for democratization in Georgia. He pledged to increase opposition participation in decision-making, leading to potential progress in political pluralism. Analysts believe that opposition parties could benefit from increased visibility and gain votes in upcoming legislative elections. Saakashvili's victory also reassured international investors of Georgia's stable investment climate, although increased social spending may lead to short-term inflation. The Secretary General of the Council of Europe urged opposition politicians to address electoral irregularities through constitutional procedures. Thousands peacefully protested against a fraudulent election, claiming Saakashvili did not win enough votes to avoid a run-off. Observers note a decline in public trust in Saakashvili's governance despite his electoral victory. Despite a decline in public trust in Saakashvili's governance, citizens fear voting for opposition candidates due to past disorder. Saakashvili's win dealt a blow to Russia's influence in Georgia, raising concerns about tensions. His pledge to unify Georgia peacefully aims to reassure Russia, with his re-election seen as a positive example. Saakashvili's re-election provides a positive example to reform-minded politicians in Russia and other Soviet successor states. The U.S. State Department welcomed his call for early elections and urged him to restore media broadcasts for a fair election. Deputy Assistant Secretary of State Matthew Bryza visited Tbilisi with proposals to restore democratic reform in Georgia. The United States sees democracy as a top priority in Georgia, urging government and opposition politicians to compromise for democratic progress. The US supports Georgia's NATO aspirations but suggests waiting for further political developments before considering a Membership Action Plan. NATO's decision may be delayed beyond the April 2008 Summit in Bucharest to assess Georgia's performance in the upcoming legislative election. Georgia's performance in the May 2008 legislative election was praised by the State Department, but concerns were raised about electoral violations. The US ambassador to Georgia did not officially congratulate a winner until after the final election results were announced. President Bush congratulated Saakashvili and sent a representative to his inauguration, leading to criticism from some opposition supporters. Supporters in Georgia criticized the United States for recognizing Saakashvili's win, reflecting potential increase in anti-Americanism. The 110th Congress supported democratization in Georgia and urged NATO to extend a Membership Action Plan for Georgia. The Senate approved a resolution urging the U.S. President to support free and fair elections in Georgia. Senator Richard Lugar expressed strong support for the Georgian people. Richard Lugar expressed strong support for the Georgian people and their democratic path, urging Georgia to facilitate international election monitors. Representative Alcee Hastings led a mission of short-term observers who viewed the election as a viable expression of free choice, but cautioned about future challenges due to mistrust and polarization in Georgian society. Former Representative Jim Kolbe evaluated the election as broadly free and fair. The International Republican Institute evaluated the election as broadly free and fair, but called for further reforms.
